text: The second target of the influenza virus is the envelope protein neuraminidase.
Surface aggregation reduces the number of virus particles released.
Neuraminidase inhibitors prevent sialic acid cleavage, causing the virus particles to aggregate at the cell surface.
Unencumbered, the virus can leave the cell surface and infect another cell.
Unfortunately, amantadine-resistant strains of influenza have developed, in part because of the widespread use of amantadine by Chinese poultry farmers.
However, flu symptoms generally last only 3–10 days.
The enzyme cleaves any sialic acid on the cell surface that may have bound to the hemagglutinin on the virus.
The result is fusion of the two membranes and release of the virion into the cytoplasm.
The neuraminidase inhibitors, when used within 48 hours of disease onset, decrease shedding and reduce the duration of influenza symptoms by approximately one day.
The newer antiflu drugs, such as viral envelope allows virus particles to leave the cell in which they were made.
The drop in pH changes the structure of hemagglutinin on the viral membrane so that it can now bind to receptors on the endocytic membrane.

While this does not sound like a substantial benefit, shortening the course of the flu in the elderly can minimize damage to the lungs, which in turn reduces the chance of developing life-threatening secondary bacterial infections such as pneumonia and bronchitis.
For hemagglutinin structure to change, the interior of the enveloped virion must also be acidified.
As a result, the drug is no longer recommended as a treatment for influenza.
